chapter.title: Styling Your Documents
chapter.p: For each supported output format, there exists a subfolder transform/<format> below the installation folder. Inside this folder, the XSL stylesheets with the transformation rules for this target format and a style definition file style.xml are stored.

To modify the style definition for a given target format, create and edit a copy of the corresponding style.xml file. Then use the -s command line switch to point the document processor to the new style file. The format and contents of the style definition file differ depending on the output format.

section.title: Editing the CSS-Stylesheet
section.p: The central style definition for XHTML is an old-fashioned CSS stylesheet, wrapped inside an XML container. For users who have previous experience with CSS, most parts of the stylesheet should be straight-forward to figure out. The following subsections focus on pointing out the elements of the stylesheet concerning the page layout.

minisection.title: Frontpage and Table of Contents
minisection.p: The document head, carrying for example the title, authors, date of publication, publisher and copyright details, is set inside a div section with the id #head,

marked with a red outline in figure . The header elements themselves are arranged in a table with style class head, marked by the blue outline in figure . Each element is contained in a separate cell with style class head-element, e.g. head-title. The subtitle is set in the same cell as the main title, but wrapped in an extra div with style class subtitle, so that it can be styled differently from the main title.

The table of contents (TOC) is contained inside a div section with id #toc, marked with a red outline in figure . The TOC heading and list of headings are set in divs with style class toc-heading and listof-heading, respectively. The entries in the TOC are divs with style classes toc-mainitem and toc-subitem, the empty elements in between sections have style class toc-spacer. The indentation of the TOC entries cannot be influenced through the CSS stylesheet, as it is applied dynamically during transformation.

minisection.title: Navigation Elements
minisection.p: The top navigation bar is set inside a div section with id nav-top, which in turns contains a table with the same style class name. The table has a cell nav-top-title displaying the document title and a cell nav-top-buttons containing the navigations buttons.

Analogously, the bottom navigation bar consists of a div with id nav-bottom containing a table carrying the same style class name. This table is split into three cells nav-bottom-left, nav-bottom-center and nav-bottom-right. The text labels and links to previous, next and superordinate sections (see fig. ) are styled in separate spans with style classes nav-link-dir and nav-link, respectively.
